section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children through dance, and introduce vocabulary (grow, cuddled).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book How Kids Grow and asking, What can babies do?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and answer questions to seek help or information.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of words that communicate feelings, needs, and wants.
Show understanding of spoken language.
Talk and share.
Use information to describe; Relate own experiences to those in books.
Describe the passing of time.
Identify unique characteristics of families.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children use language to describe concepts associated with the passing of time, such as in the morning, at night, before, after, first, last, how long, and longer.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find a book with photos of babies or of older children? What are they doing?
What age can you pretend to be? What will you do at that age?
Can you draw a picture of what you do first each day? Last?
Can you write or draw about how you’ve changed since you were a baby?
How can you make a table for a pretend tea party? What will you serve? Who will you invite?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word baby? Can you write the letter?
What materials can you use to make a bed for a baby? For a child? For an adult? How are they different?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Kids Grow by Jean Marzollo, photographs by Nancy Sheehan. Text copyright © 1998 by Jean Marzollo. Photographs copyright © 1998 by Nancy Sheehan. Published by Scholastic Inc.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the persistence Mind Builder and introduce vocabulary (solve problems, goals).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to How Kids Grow.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand and use varied types of words that communicate feeling, needs, and wants; Understand multiple-meaning words; Understand and use varied types of words.
Show understanding of spoken language.
Persist in tasks.
Talk and share.
Show self-awareness in different/multiple ways
Express pride in age-appropriate skills
Tolerate frustration as a step to learning.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Use technology, including learning applications, to express own ideas.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity; Emotional Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children look at and discuss pictures of children persisting to learn something or to achieve a goal.
Lead children in discussing the importance of not giving up.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find a book that shows children doing something you don’t know how to do yet?
Can you act as if you’re a baby learning to walk?
Can you find toy figures to show four members of a family? How do you know there are four?
What have you learned to do by persisting and not giving up? Can you write or draw about it?
Can you make a necklace for a friend? How many pieces will it have?
Can you use the alphabet chart to find the letters in your name? Which letter of your name is a capital letter?
Can you build a set of stairs? What will be at the top?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Kids Grow by Jean Marzollo, photographs by Nancy Sheehan. Text copyright © 1998 by Jean Marzollo. Photographs copyright © 1998 by Nancy Sheehan. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background and introduce vocabulary (crawl, wave).
Begin Story Time by revisiting How Kids Grow and asking the guiding question, What are some things that we learn to do by practicing?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Relate own experiences to those in books; Use information to describe.
Compose an informative text; Write for different purposes.
Identify unique characteristics of families.
Describe the life cycles of different plants and animals.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts; Use perception to guide movement through space and interactions with objects and people.
Show emerging proficiency on tasks requiring eye-hand coordination.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Social Studies: People, Past and Present

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children describe traits of families.
Encourage children to describe themselves as members of a family.
Discuss people at different ages (e.g., baby, adult, elderly).
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Find a book about animals. How are all the animals alike? How are they different?
Can you wave goodbye? What will you say as you wave?
How can you compare the ages of two friends? How can you tell which friend is older?
Can you write about one thing you learned to do this year?
How many people are in your family? Can you draw them?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word wave? What other words do you know that begin with the same sound?
Can you use blocks to build a house for a pretend family? How many people will be in this family? Who are they?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Kids Grow by Jean Marzollo, photographs by Nancy Sheehan. Text copyright © 1998 by Jean Marzollo. Photographs copyright © 1998 by Nancy Sheehan. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: What We Have Learned

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to review what children have learned this year and introduce vocabulary words (investigate, discover).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts What We Have Learned and How Kids Grow.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question, How have we changed?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Ask and answer questions to seek help or information.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Relate own experiences to those in books; Compare and contrast two stories relating to the same topic.
Write for different purposes.
Understand differences between living and nonliving things.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts; Use perception to guide movement through space and interactions with objects and people.
Show emerging proficiency on tasks requiring eye-hand coordination.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to identify and distinguish between living and nonliving things.
Discuss nonliving things in nature.
Discuss what all living things need to grow.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Find a book about a family. What are the children in this book doing? Can you do these things?
You are a kitten! What will you have to learn from your mother?
Can you put these vehicles in order from slowest to fastest?
Can you write or draw about something you enjoyed learning in school this year?
What nonliving thing can you draw or make with clay?
Can you show me which letter makes the beginning sound you hear in the word discover?
Can you build a home for a very tiny animal? Will the animal live in water or on land? What will the animal eat?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Kids Grow by Jean Marzollo, photographs by Nancy Sheehan. Text copyright © 1998 by Jean Marzollo. Photographs copyright © 1998 by Nancy Sheehan. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out pages from How Kids Grow and to introduce vocabulary words (point, build).
Begin Story Time by revisiting How Kids Grow and asking, What will you be able to do when you’re five and six years old?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding of text read aloud.
Understand and use a growing number of words that communicate feelings, needs, and wants; Understand and use varied types of words.
Show understanding of spoken language.
Produce at least 20 letter-sound correspondences.
Use information to describe; Relate own experiences to those in books.
Compose an informative text; Write for different purposes; Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompt; Use perception to guide movement through space and interactions with objects and people.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they respond to this week’s prompt: What was the hardest thing that you learned how to do? How did you learn to do it?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s work to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What will you be able to do when you’re five and six years old?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote your own book about how babies grow, what would you include in it?
Can you pretend that you are six or seven and are trying to put on the clothes you’re wearing now? Will they fit you?
How can you measure which child in our class is the tallest?
Create a story about what you will be when you grow up.
Can you draw or paint a picture of yourself as an adult?
Can you find the letters that you would put on a birthday card? What words would you spell?
What materials could you use to build a sandbox? What toys would you include?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. How Kids Grow by Jean Marzollo, photographs by Nancy Sheehan. Text copyright © 1998 by Jean Marzollo. Photographs copyright © 1998 by Nancy Sheehan. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Talk and share.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Use language to describe concepts associated with the passing of time.
Identify similarities and differences in characteristics of families.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Talk and share.
Show self-awareness and express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills.
Name at least 20 uppercase and at least 20 lowercase letters in the language of instruction.
Use digital learning applications and programs to create digital products and express own ideas.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Identify similarities and differences in characteristics of families.
Describe life cycles of organisms.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Show increasing control of tasks that require eye-hand coordination.
Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Show increasing control of tasks that require eye-hand coordination.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Produce at least 20 distinct letter-sound correspondences in the language of instruction.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language, and verbally share meaning.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
